title: Friday, 17th March, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Have a pic for Friday

PM11:01am

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Helena Morrissey, formerly of Newton

PM11:01am

Now the FT's Boldness in Business person of the year

PM11:02am

We never did choose our person of interest at Xmas

11:01 am
PM11:02am

But then we never do, i guess

PM11:02am

https://www.ft.com...-944b-e7eb37a6aa8e

PM11:02am

And yes, it's Gold Cup day etc

11:02 am
PM11:02am

undefined
PM11:02am

First tho...

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Tony T just at the desk here

PM11:03am

Saying the US has formally apologised for this GCHQ nonsense

PM11:03am

Telegraph has a story apparently.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Maybe kick off on that Bryce?

PM11:04am

Any movement with Sky?

PM11:04am

Reason I ask is that bid arbs are often blind to political tail risks, i think

11:04 am
PM11:04am

We have a situation where Fox News thinks it's just fine to put a wingnut on the box -- who makes wild claims

PM11:05am

Which then get picked up by the clowns around Trump

BE11:05am

There is, as you say, no movement.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Which end up in...

PM11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-97d1-5e720a26771b

PM11:06am

A spokesperson for the agency said: “Recent allegations made by media commentator Judge Andrew Napolitano about GCHQ being asked to conduct ‘wire tapping’ against the then president-elect are nonsense.

“They are utterly ridiculous and should be ignored.”

11:05 am
BE11:06am

There was a good report from ITV's Joel Hills overnight about the lack of risk priced into Sky ....

BE11:06am

http://www.itv.com...-enemy-number-one/

PM11:06am

I know we have bias rules with broadcasters here

11:06 am
PM11:06am

But it's a matter of journalistic competence

PM11:07am

If you give your airways over to freaks you maybe shouldn't be allowed by control Sky

BE11:07am

I note in passing that Fox News falls under Ofcom's justification, due to it being available over here, and has only been censured three times.

11:07 am
PM11:08am

Ah, does it

BE11:09am

There was a censure for the "Birmingham is a Muslim stronghold" thing, if I remember correctly. But generally, Fox News's UK regulatory record is no better nor worse than any other channel.

BE11:09am

Anyway, that ITV report quotes Lord Grade as saying of Murdoch: "In those days he had a power and a political clout that he doesn't have today."

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Which I think is the consensus opinion here. He's yesterday's man.

PM11:10am

Except Fox New currently bending US/UK relations...

PM11:10am

Anyway, let's move on

11:10 am
undefined
PM11:10am

And so to Bob Diamond

BE11:10am

Speaking of yesterday's men ...........

11:10 am
PM11:10am

hehehe

BE11:11am

So! The Panmure rescue came from leftfield.

PM11:11am

Bob's shiny comeback, etc

11:11 am
BE11:11am

We've been banging on for some time about Panmure being unofficially for sale, with all sorts of names linked. Arden, Cenkos, etc.

BE11:12am

Instead, we have a take-private by Qinvest and Bob.

undefined
11:12 am
BE11:13am

Breaking news

BE11:13am

https://twitter.com/mrevgenylebedev/status/842694795164303360

BE11:13am

Is that genuine?!?!?!

11:13 am
BE11:13am

https://twitter.com/mrevgenylebedev/status/842694891356479488

BE11:13am

https://twitter.com/mrevgenylebedev/status/842694991612985344

BE11:13am

https://twitter.com/mrevgenylebedev/status/842695095052881922

11:13 am
PM11:13am

We don't know whether Lebedev has been hacked, currently

PM11:14am

Danger

PM11:14am

We're kinda speechless this end

11:14 am
BE11:14am

BBC's Amol Rajan seems to have confirmed it, or at least believes it.

PM11:15am

It's bloody well true

BE11:15am

So, Osborne worked (briefly) for the Telegraph after leaving uni.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

He has some journalistic experience.

BE11:16am

In 1993, Osborne intended to pursue a career in journalism. He was shortlisted for but failed to gain a place on The Times trainee scheme; Osborne also applied to The Economist, where he was interviewed and rejected by Gideon Rachman.[11] In the end he had to settle for freelance work on the Peterborough diary column of The Daily Telegraph.[12] Some time later an Oxford friend of his, journalist George Bridges, alerted Osborne to a research vacancy at Conservative Central Office.[12]

BE11:16am

That's from Wikipedia, of course. The first port of call on all breaking news stories.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

I mean ...... he has more journalistic experience than the chap who runs City AM. But still ...................

BE11:17am

......... I guess "relevant experience" in his CV isn't what I should be focusing on here.

PM11:18am

http://blogs.ft.co...ns-new-chancellor/

11:18 am
PM11:18am

In theory, I should know Britain’s new chancellor of the exchequer, really quite well. George Osborne grew up in the same street as me in London. We went to the same school. He used to be called Gideon, before changing his name to George. I once interviewed him for a job. But the odd thing is, I hardly know the guy.

The reason for this is rather humiliating. The chancellor, as I will have to learn to call him, is much younger than me. Eight years younger, to be precise; he has only just turned 39. So the first time I really met George Osborne was when I interviewed him for a job at The Economist in 1997.

BE11:19am

Well, anyway. I hope George enjoys his future of choosing the direction of stories about the Royal Oak bypass.

BE11:19am

Let's get back to the day job.

11:19 am
undefined
PM11:19am

Better than working for a living, this

BE11:20am

So, Bob then. Failed in Rwanda try London.

11:19 am
Panmure Gordon & Co PLC (PMR:LSE): Last: 98.00, up 38.5 (+64.71%), Volume: 257.19k
PM11:20am

Shareholders get to stay with the new unlisted vehicle if they wish

BE11:20am

Yeah, the contingent funding agreement suggests they probably shouldn't.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Which might do as well as Bob's previous comeback vehicle

PM11:20am

PM11:21am

Atlas Mara

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Rude also not to include Panmure's long-term chart.

BE11:21am

PM11:21am

ouch

11:21 am
BE11:22am

2000 was great, wasn't it? An absolute hoot.

BE11:22am

So, deal value of £15m

BE11:22am

But with a £5m loan note attached, so £20m EV

11:22 am
BE11:22am

That's for £23m of revenue last year, on which (obviously) it made a loss.

BE11:23am

What does it say for this desperately beleaguered sector? Not a lot.

BE11:23am

Here's Jeremy Grime of FinnCap ..........

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Cenkos produced £76m revenue in 2015 after £89m in 2014 and trades at £53m mkt cap. In EV terms the valuation is 26% of revenue. Numis trades at an EV/revenue of 1.89X. There are reasons for the wide valuation differentials and I suspect this is a special situation rather than having any sector implications.

BE11:24am

One could argue the main positive here for Cenkos is that they're not buying Panmure, but to do so would be cruel and unnecessary.

undefined
11:24 am
PM11:24am

Actually, on the subject of diamonds

PM11:25am

This has to be the most opportunistic RNS of the year so far...

PM11:25am

Stellar Diamonds plc

("Stellar" or the "Company")

709 Carat Diamond Discovered in Sierra Leone

PM11:25am

http://www.investe...1703170700097521Z/

PM11:25am

PM11:26am

Some pastor found it -- and its locked up in the Sierra Leone central bank for safe keeping

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Still

PM11:26am

Cant autoquote bu the stock is up 5%

undefined
11:26 am
BE11:27am

Moving on ......

BE11:27am

We have Tullow pulling the trigger on a cash call that's far too small to solve its problems.

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 200.60, down 36.7 (-15.47%), High: 215.00, Low: 199.80, Volume: 19.67m
11:27 am
PM11:27am

http://www.investe...1703170708417837Z/

PM11:28am

What I want to know is why it's not a simple 1-for-2

PM11:28am

Instead 25-for-49

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Omg smile

PM11:28am

But you reckon it's just too small??

BE11:29am

Yeah, it looks like it's a patch-up measure

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Give it enough headroom rather than take off the risks further down the line and turn back into an explorer.

BE11:30am

UBS also notes that the shares are down 30% since mid January, so the timing's a bit of a frustration.

BE11:31am

While Tullow has begun deleveraging since last August's TEN start-up, near-term FCF generation is still limited - we estimate just $200m this year excluding disposal proceeds and close to zero in 2018E as TEN drilling restarts and (higher-margin) Business Insurance barrels roll off. We have previously calculated that Tullow's headroom would become uncomfortably tight (smaller than $30m) following April 2018 amortisations, even if all discretionary spend (Kenya, Jubilee FFD, E&A) was deferred. We believe today's announcement provides sufficient liquidity to get through 2018E but Tullow may still need to refinance its $3.3bn RBL and/or farm-down Kenya to avoid the risk of value leakage through project deferrals in 2019E and beyond. 2017E ND/EBITDA falls from 3.9x to 3.3x and 2018E from 3.9x to 3.2x - still well above the 2.5x long-term target.

11:00 am
PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:31am

I won't go on about risk free underwriting -- but have you seen how many banks are on this?

PM11:31am

The Rights Issue, which is subject to Shareholder approval, is fully underwritten by Barclays Bank PLC, acting through its investment bank and J.P. Morgan Securities plc (which conducts its UK investment banking business as J.P. Morgan Cazenove) acting as Joint Global Coordinators, Joint Sponsors and Joint Bookrunners, Morgan Stanley acting as Joint Bookrunner, and BNP Paribas, Crédit Agricole CIB and Société Générale acting as Co-Bookrunners.

· DNB Markets, a part of DNB Bank ASA, ING Bank N.V., Natixis and Nedbank Limited, acting through its corporate and investment bank, are acting as Co-Lead Managers.

11:31 am
PM11:32am

10 banks

BE11:32am

To be fair, finding a right price for a Tullow cash call isn't simple, since its gearing means it's up and down 10% every day on no news whatsoever.

BE11:32am

They've shared the risk around, certainly.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Adjusting our NAV for the share issuance and $750m proceeds, we estimate our Risked NAV falls from £2.58/sh to £2.20/sh and Commercial NAV from £2.47/sh to £2.12/sh (we treat convertibles as equity, hence lower headline % dilution).

BE11:33am

That's UBS. This is RBC.

BE11:33am

Tullow has been underperforming the oil price and its peers in recent days, and this morning the company announced a 25 for 49 rights issue, priced at 130p, to raise ~£590m (net). The fundraising should accelerate the recovery of Tullow’s balance sheet, but the placing is likely to satisfy investor demand for a stock that sits outside most indices; therefore, without a material pick-up in activity, the share price recovery could be sluggish. With that said, the fundraising is straight out of 1998-2003's oil price collapse recovery playbook, so we need to ask - has Tullow inadvertently put itself in play?

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Use of proceeds: With a stronger balance sheet Tullow intends to accelerate the pace of growth over the next three to five years by invest in further infill drilling opportunities in both its operated and non-operated portfolio; undertaking exploration and appraisal around the Jubilee and TEN fields to further develop the high return near field resource base; undertake further exploration and appraisal activity in Kenya to further prove up the resource base; drill high-impact, potentially high return prospects across Tullow's African and South American portfolio; and new ventures.

In play: CNOOC has today preempted the Total deal in Uganda, which demonstrates interest in that asset and we see no reason why similar interest should not be exhibited in Kenya. Ghana has world class assets and Tullow’s refocused exploration potential has promise, and its value is not reflected in the current share price, in our view. The key wrinkle is the border dispute in Ghana that should be resolved in late 2017.

BE11:33am

Our view: We were awaiting the 2004 playbook play: Exploration success.

BE11:34am

I've spent too much of my life doing Tullow bid rumours to give that theme much time right now.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Deutsche.

BE11:35am

The decision to raise funds at this stage may come as a surprise and should prompt questions as to what has changed in 1Q17 to prompt this action now? (leadership change? a bearish signal of the lower-for-longer mantra? appetite for deals?). As such, we expect some equity discontent on the conference call that management did not commit to a rights issue when the share price was stronger. Nonetheless, we think that the rights issue has been attractively priced for existing shareholders and believe the c.15% short position will also provide an outlet for any excess on the fully underwritten rights.

undefined

PM11:35am

While on E&P...

PM11:35am

I mentioned this Bowleven raid the other day

http://www.investe...1703150700094834Z/

PM11:36am

11:37 am
PM11:37am

But the chairman, Billy Allan is apparently refusing to accept reality

PM11:37am

He's trying to keep the ceo Kevin Hart on as ceo, even tho he's been voted off the board

PM11:37am

And so the rebels are going to have to call another of those things we used to call EGMs

11:37 am
PM11:38am

To clear Allan out as well

PM11:38am

Actually, one of the shareholders has copied me in on an email

PM11:38am

Subject: Attention of Billy

Katie please pass this on, THANK YOU
Billy
The General Meeting of shareholders voted
You can't ignore the vote
Whilst I have been a big supporter of BLVN ( holding within family in SIP and ISA's over 3 million shares ) I recognised all but one of the proposals were passed
To dismiss you wasn't ( but that was by the finest of margins)
I understand you effectively and unilaterally have decided to carry on usual
That we are continuing as before but without Kevin sitting on the Board
That is outrageous and you should be held accountable by the shareholders to respect their decision
We did not need to sell our holding in Etende down by such a huge amount
We should have taken some risk off the table but we did not need to raise that much cash AND what have we done with it!
We are now under new management and you can't ignore and simply retain Kevin in his role and have him reporting directly to you
You do yourself a huge disservice
Richard ( Boddie )

11:38 am
Bowleven PLC (BLVN:LSE): Last: 34.62, up 0.3738 (+1.09%), High: 35.50, Low: 33.75, Volume: 1.84m
PM11:39am

Fun and games there, for sure

Jupiter Fund Management PLC (JUP:LSE): Last: 423.00, up 2.5 (+0.59%), High: 426.10, Low: 419.90, Volume: 1.63m

http://www.investe...1703170700087819Z/

BE11:44am

Deal with AstraZeneca for COPD.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

(@ROTR: if I've already said I'll not give specifics then chucking random names at me like mortars is unlikely to be a winning tactic.)

PM11:45am

Actually, what is COPD?

BE11:45am

Hope you never have to find out. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

As in, your lungs don't work.

PM11:46am

oh

BE11:46am

Narrowed airways, resulting in slow and very painful death.

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Well im glad there's a treatment for it

PM11:47am

Duaklir

PM11:47am

Sorry, Duaklir®

11:47 am
BE11:47am

There are lots of treatments, though there are also lots of strains of COPD.

BE11:48am

Let me grab .... Kepler, maybe? ... from the AZN perspective.

BE11:48am

Astra has entered into a collaboration agreement with Circassia for the development and commercialisation of Tudorza and Duaklir in the US. Under the terms of the collaboration, Circassia will lead promotion of Tudorza in the US and has been granted an option to hold full commercial rights in the future. Circassia has also been granted the rights to Duaklir in the US. The agreement is expected to be completed in Q2 2017. Conditions for Almirall will not change, as the company will continue to receive milestones and royalties from the sale of both products in the US. Astra will complete the ongoing development programmes and will continue to manufacture and supply both medicines. According to Almirall, the agreement reinforces its positive view about potential US milestones, as Circassia will be fully devoted to the commercialisation of both products. Also, Circassia plans to double its US salesforce. The final impact for Almirall is yet to be seen, but we do not think this should be negative for future sales of both products. In our view, the move is more related to Astra’s strategy to generate externalisation revenues from non-core assets (increasingly anything that is not oncology) to generate cash to pay for R&D. From our EUR17.5 per share TP, milestones from Astra account for EUR1.6 per share, of which the US is close to 70%. Royalties are only EUR0.7 per share (also c. 70% coming from the US).

11:50 am
BE11:50am

And Numis, from the Circassia perspective.

BE11:51am

Oh. They're restricted.

BE11:51am

Which is a pity, because Paul Cuddon's a really good analyst.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

But Numis is sole sponsor. Here's his notes anyway.

BE11:52am

These products were acquired by AZ from Actavis in Feb-2015 (Source: AZ press release) but originate from Almirall, who had partnered with Forest in the US in 2006 (Source: www.biospace.com) and allow AZ to “sharpen our focus on Symbicort, Bevespi Aerosphere, benralizumab and other respiratory development programs”. They will immediately add on-market revenues and are a “clear strategic fit” with Circassia’s focus on respiratory medicines, leveraging and enhancing existing commercial infrastructure. Turdoza (a long acting muscarinic antagonist) is approved in the US, and approximately 60 countries around the world and generated $170m in 2016 ($80m in the US). Duaklir (a combination of Turdoza and a long-acting beta agonist, a so-called LAMA/LABA) is approved in approximately 50 countries around the world and is in Phase 3 development in the US (AMPLIFY, 1,500 patients, source: Clinicaltrials.gov) with primary completion expected in June 2017 (Source: clinicaltrials.gov). The trial is focussed on the 400µg/12µg dose.

BE11:53am

Sorry I can't give any value on this, but I don't know and I don't know who to ask.

11:52 am
undefined
PM11:53am

Best share Cheltenham stuff

PM11:53am

Here's the Shrewdette for the final day

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Nearly managed to give back all my previous days winnings but thanks to Lil Rockerfeller running a blinder in second managed to keep ahead - just. So, on to arguably the most emotional Gold Cup in years - go Cue Card!

1:30 JCB Triumph Hurdle. By all accounts JP McManus has the one-two sown up with 5 time winner DEFI DU SEUIL 9/4 and Charli Parts 7/2. But for me its the handsome son of Mastercraftsman MASTER BLUEYES - routed the field last time out and an attractively priced 7/1. SkyBet money back offer still on so what’s to lose.

2:10 County H’cap Hurdle. Wide open betting race - lots in with chances. Sky paying 6 places @ 1/5, & 365 5 at 1/4. All picks each-way - AIR HORSE ONE 14/1 going for a 4-timer, NORTH HILL HARVEY 7/1 won the Greatwood and the yard won this last year, IVANOVICH GORBATOV 10/1 down in class today & would be lovely to see Joseph O’Brien have a first winner here, and a sentimental pick - real outsider DOMINADA 33/1 made the journey down from Yorkshire - can’t see him winning but might run 6th!

2:50 Albert Bartlett Novice Hurdle. WHOLESTONE 7/1 really clicked this season winning 3 times at Cheltenham. DEATH DUTY 2/1 fav, winner from Ireland and this track should suit. PaddyPower paying 4 places so a small flutter on THE WORLDS END 8/1grade 2 winner at Haydock and worth a place in this field.

3:30 the big one - The Gold Cup. I have been ante-post CUE CARD for some months and just took Hills’ early morning offer 11/2 to top up. He’s a grand old boy - won his first race before his rivals were born - fell in this last year at the 3rd last - but I am emotionally attached to him so won’t be moved. I’ve coupled his stablemate NATIVE RIVER 5/1 to complete a Tizzard trained one-two. Poor DJAKADAM 3/1 fav the bridesmaid twice running, better not spoil the people’s party!

4:10 Foxhunter Challenge Open Hunters Chase. ON THE FRINGE 7/4 fav seeking a hat-trick in this race the one to beat. And each-way on PAINT THE CLOUDS 12/1 3rd in the last 2 runnings of this and will like today’s going. PaddyPower paying 4 places.

4:50 Conditional Jockeys’ H’cap Hurdle. NO COMMENT 6/1 fav arrives on a hat-trick. COO STAR SIVOLA 12/1 EW gutsy winner on New Years Day will be ridden by Lizzie Kelly who earlier will have been the first female rider in the Gold Cup. And a longer priced each way VERNI 20/1 very lightly raced but progressive & a last time out winner. Sky goes 6 @1/5, 365 5 @ 1/4.

5:30 Grand annual Challenge Cup H’cap Chase. LE PREZIEN 6/1 Promising novice chaser on a favourable mark & Nichols/Twiston-D need a winner. SOLAR IMPULSE 40/1 EW won this last year but form since a little down but I’m having a small flutter to run a place (would be lovely for Brian Hughes to grab a winner too).

PM11:53am

So she's going for Cue Card for the Gold Cup itself

BE11:53am

Thumbs up

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Good luck with those, people

PM11:54am

chad_john -- she had a good day two, but yeah

BE11:54am

Horse racing tipster in "not entirely reliable" shocker.

11:54 am
undefined
BE11:55am

Sellside-wise, it seems RBS is leading us up.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 246.40, up 5.8 (+2.41%), High: 246.90, Low: 242.40, Volume: 10.78m
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Natixis pushing.

BE11:55am

The investment thesis for RBS is reaching a turning point. The time is near when the long-standing strengths of the Core bank will outweigh the material drag of legacy items. Management, which has built a reputation for realism, foresees a statutory profit in 2018 after 10 consecutive years of losses. We upgrade our rating to Buy.

BE11:56am

..... though when they say "reaching" a turning point, they mean next decade.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Financial performance is not expected to normalise until 2020 and profitability for the coming 4 years will be underpinned by a further £2bn cost reduction initiative. Having obtained greater clarity on normalised performance (RoTE of at least 12%, cost/income ratio less than 50%), we are now basing our target price of 289p on 2020 estimates. This is 29% higher than our previous target price.

BE11:57am

Brexit, tho. All fine there.

BE11:57am

Fears concerning the impact of Brexit on what is increasingly a UK-focused business have not materialised yet and our central case is now for a less severe economic slow-down. Relative to other UK banks the RBS investment case includes more upside from self-help factors (cost reduction, above average growth in Core markets) and the cessation of historic problems (litigation, de-risking).

11:57 am
BE11:57am

.... oh, should mention ......

BE11:57am

EU SAID TO RULE OUT U.K. TRADE TALKS BEFORE BREXIT PAYMENT DEAL

PM11:58am

Where's that appeared?

11:57 am
BE11:58am

That was a Bloomberg flash about half an hour ago. £'s down a bit on it.

PM11:58am

Euro also under some press

PM11:58am

Fresh poll out on Le Pen?

11:58 am
PM11:58am

think so

BE11:59am

Anyway, back to Natixis.

BE11:59am

We see limited excess capital in today’s balance sheet but do anticipate the emergence of a highly capital generative bank post restructuring. Our valuation is based predominantly upon intrinsic profitability and future organic capital generation. We assume that dividend payments will resume in 2018 following resolution of US litigation and expect that the ability to generate returns above the cost of equity will support attractive yield characteristics for the shares.

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

In line with management aspirations, we model more than 30p of EPS on a statutory basis for 2020. In view of likely low levels of RWA growth we think this could support DPS (including a special dividend) of 27.5p. These projections are long-dated but the implied PER of 7.7x and yield greater than 10% illustrate upside potential for the shares. After multiple years of erosion, we expect TNAV will trough at end 2017 at 264p. RBS is a bank capable of generating double digit returns trading at a discount to tangible book value.

undefined
BE12:00pm

@Soundbuy: Barclays shoving Weir, I think.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Part of a capital goods sector note that I've not read.

BE12:01pm

The green shoots in mining capex are starting to emerge after a 4-year downturn. Miners are now generating strong cash flows, deleveraging balance sheets rapidly and – as is now clear from their 2017 budgets – stepping up capital spending again. In this report, we analyze miners’ capex budgets in detail, discuss what’s driving higher spending in 2017-18, and assess the implications for our European mining equipment sector. In tandem, we refresh our views and ratings: Atlas Copco remains a key Overweight (price target moves to SEK350); we upgrade Weir to Overweight (EW); Sandvik moves to Equal Weight (UW); and Metso remains EW.

BE12:01pm

That's the gist.

12:01 pm

BE12:03pm

BE12:03pm

While Berkeley’s AGM IMS as usual juggled the skills of being brief but political, it nonetheless packed a punch across a range of topics. For investors focused on sentiment (and it has been this that has held the stock back in the last year), the news that the market has stabilized, reservations are up in the past 2 months, and pricing remains above planned levels should reassure. For those focused on the business itself the guidance of FY 17 PBT to top end of consensus and the same for FY 18 drives 5-6% upside to consensus, with the order book providing the confidence for this. For those focused on yield, there is 2.8% yield in March, with a further 3.3% (100p equivalent) in Sep 17.

BE12:04pm

Over the past months the share price of Berkeley has recovered somewhat, although still 20% from its Jan 2016 levels. For a group capable of a long term ROE of 20%, trading at 1.3x 2018 NTAV we see the stock as too cheap. BUY

PM12:04pm

PM12:04pm

BERKELEY GROUP^ (BKG, HOLD at 2963p) – trading update. An unscheduled trading update for the first 10 months of the year is, as they often are here, more a statement or comment about the state of the market and a comment on the political environment as it relates to housing in the capital. The statement does indicate that profits for the year to April will be at the upper end of expectations but this is not especially relevant because FY2017 and FY2018 are the winding down of the ‘old’ Berkeley Group, the one that did spectacularly well in the prime central London market.

The ‘what next’ question had begun to be answered in the interims in December and this statement confirms still that Berkeley goes from being an £800m per annum PBT business to £500m PBT. However, if profits in the next two years are likely to be a little higher than previously stated and the five year total outlook remains at £3bn in aggregate, then the expected £500m may be a touch high. That there are likely to be more nearer term profits should not really impact on the valuation but in the current and more excitable climate in the sector because of bid activity, we would expect the share to jump.

Overall, we should not be diverted by the comments on dividend and buy-backs as the board does not appear to be making any cash or redemption payments more than already expected so this also should have no impact on the valuation. Overall, this remains a very good business but what the business profile and sustainable profit level will be do remain a little uncertain and we stick with a HOLD recommendation – the midcaps still offer the best value in the sector and it may even be worth looking at taking some profit here if we see the shares above 3000p.
